Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stood in my tiny kitchen, nervously smoothing the plastic wrap over the cake I’d baked. As a new neighbor, I wanted to make a good impression, maybe even spark a friendship or two. I’d seen Mrs. Kim from next door watering her plants, and I told myself I’d bring the cake over as soon as I finished this last bit of work. But my laptop chimed again—another urgent message from my project manager. The team was waiting on my core module, and the build couldn’t move forward until I finished. I could almost feel the weight of their expectations through the screen: the project timeline was tight, and everyone was counting on me to deliver. Yet, the thought of Mrs. Kim going back inside before I could say hello gnawed at me. I wanted to be the kind of neighbor who was present, friendly, and polite, not the one who was always too busy. My hands hovered between the cake and the keyboard, my mind torn between the warmth of a new connection and the cold logic of a looming deadline.
